cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
who plays voldemort in harry potter and the philosopher's stone
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process: In "Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone," the character of Voldemort is portrayed primarily through a combination of visual effects and the performance of an actor. While the physical embodiment of Voldemort in this film is done by actor Richard Bremmer, the character's voice is provided by actor Frank Dillane in the later films. However, for the first film, Richard Bremmer is credited for the role of Voldemort.

Answer: Richard Bremmer plays Voldemort in "Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone."

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
who plays voldemort in harry potter and the philosopher's stone
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
["Played by Matt Meese, the sassy character of Voldemort from the Harry Potter series has made repeated appearances in Studio C's productions.\n", 'Fiennes portrayed Lord Voldemort in the 2005 fantasy film "Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire". He returned to the role for other films of the series: "Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix", "Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince", and both "Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 1" and "Part 2". In an interview with "Empire" magazine, Fiennes said his portrayal of Voldemort was an "instinctive, visceral, physical thing".\n', 'In "Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire", Voldemort is initially only heard, possessing the scratchy, weak voice heard in the first film. By the film\'s climax, however, he appears in his physical form for the first time, played by Ralph Fiennes. As in the book, Voldemort is shown clad in dark black robes, being tall and emaciated, with no hair and yellowish teeth; his wand has a white tone and the handle appears to be made of bone; his finger nails are long and pale blue while his toe nails appear to be infected. Unlike in the book, his pupils are not cat-like and his eyes are blue, because producer David Heyman felt that his evil would not be able to be seen and would not fill the audience with fear (his eyes do briefly take on a snake-like appearance when he opens them after turning human, but quickly turn normal). As in the book, the film version of Voldemort has snake-like slit nostrils with the flesh of his nose significantly pressed back. Ralph Fiennes\' nose was not covered in makeup on the set, but was digitally removed in post-production. In this first appearance, Voldemort also has a forked tongue, but this element was removed for the subsequent films.\n', 'In "Harry Potter and the Philosopher\'s Stone", Voldemort\'s manifestation is as a face on the back of Quirrell\'s head, an effect achieved by computer generated imagery. Ian Hart, the actor who played Quirrell in the same film, provided the voice and the facial source for this character. Voldemort also appears in a scene in the Forbidden Forest where he is seen drinking the blood of a unicorn. As Voldemort\'s face was altered enough by CG work, and Hart\'s voice was affected enough, there was no confusion by Hart\'s playing of the two roles. In that film, he was also shown in a flashback sequence when he arrived at the home of James and Lily Potter to kill them. In this scene Voldemort is played by Richard Bremmer, though his face is never seen. His next appearance would be in "Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets" as the 16-year-old Tom Marvolo Riddle (portrayed by Christian Coulson).\n', 'Lord Voldemort (, in the films; born Tom Marvolo Riddle) is a fictional character and the main antagonist in J. K. Rowling\'s series of "Harry Potter" novels. Voldemort first appeared in "Harry Potter and the Philosopher\'s Stone", which was released in 1997. Voldemort appears either in person or in flashbacks in each book and its film adaptation in the series, except the third, "Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban", where he is only mentioned.\n', 'BULLET::::- 2001 - "Harry Potter and the Philosopher\'s Stone" as Swedish voice of Lord Voldemort\n', 'BULLET::::- Ralph Fiennes as Lord Voldemort, Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix\n', 'Voldemort appears in seven "Harry Potter" films, namely "Harry Potter and the Philosopher\'s Stone", "Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets", "Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire", "Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix", "Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince", "Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 1" and "Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 2". Several actors have portrayed him in his varying incarnations and ages.\n', 'From 1988-91, Hart studied video production at South Mersey College (now part of Liverpool Community College). He portrayed a POUM militia volunteer in the Spanish Civil War in "Land and Freedom" (1995), an unemployed Liverpool shipyard worker in "Liam" (2000). His best known role, however, is that of Professor Quirrell in "Harry Potter and the Philosopher\'s Stone" (2001). He also provided the voice of the CGI-generated face of Lord Voldemort.\n', "He is known for giving his Hindi dubbing voice to Ralph Fiennes's role as Lord Voldemort throughout the last Five Harry Potter films and performed along with his colleagues, Karan Trivedi (later replaced by: Rajesh Kava after the fifth film onwards), Parignya Pandya, Nachiket Dighe, Dilip Sinha and Vikrant Chaturvedi who voices Harry Potter, Hermione Jean Granger, Ronald Bilius Weasley, Rubeus Hagrid and Albus Dumbledore respectively, for the Hindi dubs of the film series.\n"]

   - In "Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone," Voldemort manifests as a face on the back of Professor Quirrell's head. This effect was achieved through computer-generated imagery (CGI).
   - Ian Hart played Professor Quirrell and provided the voice and facial source for Voldemort's character in this film.
   - Additionally, Voldemort appears in a flashback sequence where he is portrayed by Richard Bremmer, although his face is never seen in this scene.

2. **Role of CGI and Voice Acting:**
   - The use of CGI to create Voldemort's face on Quirrell's head indicates a blend of practical effects and digital technology in film-making, which may be unfamiliar to those not versed in film production techniques.
   - The fact that Ian Hart provided the voice for Voldemort while playing Quirrell highlights the complexity of character portrayal in film, where one actor can embody multiple roles through voice and physical performance.

3. **Voldemort's Character Background:**
   - Voldemort, originally known as Tom Marvolo Riddle, is the main antagonist in the Harry Potter series. His character is central to the overarching narrative of the series, which may be important for understanding his significance in the first film.

4. **Subsequent Appearances:**
   - While Ralph Fiennes is noted for portraying Voldemort in later films, it is crucial to recognize that he did not play Voldemort in "Philosopher's Stone." This distinction is important for accurately answering the question.

- **Contextualizing Voldemort:**
  Knowing that Voldemort's character is central to the series helps frame the importance of his portrayal in the first film. It sets the stage for understanding his motivations and actions throughout the series, which is crucial for any discussion about the character.

### Conclusion:
The extracted content provides a comprehensive background that aids in understanding the portrayal of Voldemort in "Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone." It highlights the roles of Ian Hart and Richard Bremmer, the use of CGI, and the character's significance within the broader narrative of the Harry Potter series. This knowledge is essential for accurately answering the original question and for a deeper appreciation of the film's production.

', "He is known for giving his Hindi dubbing voice to Ralph Fiennes's role as Lord Voldemort throughout the last Five Harry Potter films and performed along with his colleagues, Karan Trivedi (later replaced by: Rajesh Kava after the fifth film onwards), Parignya Pandya, Nachiket Dighe, Dilip Sinha and Vikrant Chaturvedi who voices Harry Potter, Hermione Jean Granger, Ronald Bilius Weasley, Rubeus Hagrid and Albus Dumbledore respectively, for the Hindi dubs of the film series.

This process aims to ensure that statements or claims are based on reliable and verifiable information while eliminating inaccurate or misleading content.

["Played by Matt Meese, the sassy character of Voldemort from the Harry Potter series has made repeated appearances in Studio C's productions.\n", 'Fiennes portrayed Lord Voldemort in the 2005 fantasy film "Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire". He returned to the role for other films of the series: "Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix", "Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince", and both "Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 1" and "Part 2". In an interview with "Empire" magazine, Fiennes said his portrayal of Voldemort was an "instinctive, visceral, physical thing".\n', 'In "Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire", Voldemort is initially only heard, possessing the scratchy, weak voice heard in the first film. By the film\'s climax, however, he appears in his physical form for the first time, played by Ralph Fiennes. As in the book, Voldemort is shown clad in dark black robes, being tall and emaciated, with no hair and yellowish teeth; his wand has a white tone and the handle appears to be made of bone; his finger nails are long and pale blue while his toe nails appear to be infected. Unlike in the book, his pupils are not cat-like and his eyes are blue, because producer David Heyman felt that his evil would not be able to be seen and would not fill the audience with fear (his eyes do briefly take on a snake-like appearance when he opens them after turning human, but quickly turn normal). As in the book, the film version of Voldemort has snake-like slit nostrils with the flesh of his nose significantly pressed back. Ralph Fiennes\' nose was not covered in makeup on the set, but was digitally removed in post-production. In this first appearance, Voldemort also has a forked tongue, but this element was removed for the subsequent films.\n', 'In "Harry Potter and the Philosopher\'s Stone", Voldemort\'s manifestation is as a face on the back of Quirrell\'s head, an effect achieved by computer generated imagery. Ian Hart, the actor who played Quirrell in the same film, provided the voice and the facial source for this character. Voldemort also appears in a scene in the Forbidden Forest where he is seen drinking the blood of a unicorn. As Voldemort\'s face was altered enough by CG work, and Hart\'s voice was affected enough, there was no confusion by Hart\'s playing of the two roles. In that film, he was also shown in a flashback sequence when he arrived at the home of James and Lily Potter to kill them. In this scene Voldemort is played by Richard Bremmer, though his face is never seen. His next appearance would be in "Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets" as the 16-year-old Tom Marvolo Riddle (portrayed by Christian Coulson).\n', 'Lord Voldemort (, in the films; born Tom Marvolo Riddle) is a fictional character and the main antagonist in J. K. Rowling\'s series of "Harry Potter" novels. Voldemort first appeared in "Harry Potter and the Philosopher\'s Stone", which was released in 1997. Voldemort appears either in person or in flashbacks in each book and its film adaptation in the series, except the third, "Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban", where he is only mentioned.\n', 'BULLET::::- 2001 - "Harry Potter and the Philosopher\'s Stone" as Swedish voice of Lord Voldemort\n', 'BULLET::::- Ralph Fiennes as Lord Voldemort, Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix\n', 'Voldemort appears in seven "Harry Potter" films, namely "Harry Potter and the Philosopher\'s Stone", "Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets", "Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire", "Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix", "Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince", "Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 1" and "Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 2". Several actors have portrayed him in his varying incarnations and ages.\n', 'From 1988-91, Hart studied video production at South Mersey College (now part of Liverpool Community College). He portrayed a POUM militia volunteer in the Spanish Civil War in "Land and Freedom" (1995), an unemployed Liverpool shipyard worker in "Liam" (2000). His best known role, however, is that of Professor Quirrell in "Harry Potter and the Philosopher\'s Stone" (2001). He also provided the voice of the CGI-generated face of Lord Voldemort.\n', "He is known for giving his Hindi dubbing voice to Ralph Fiennes's role as Lord Voldemort throughout the last Five Harry Potter films and performed along with his colleagues, Karan Trivedi (later replaced by: Rajesh Kava after the fifth film onwards), Parignya Pandya, Nachiket Dighe, Dilip Sinha and Vikrant Chaturvedi who voices Harry Potter, Hermione Jean Granger, Ronald Bilius Weasley, Rubeus Hagrid and Albus Dumbledore respectively, for the Hindi dubs of the film series.\n"]

question_info.question: who plays voldemort in harry potter and the philosopher's stone
passages:
Played by Matt Meese, the sassy character of Voldemort from the Harry Potter series has made repeated appearances in Studio C's productions.
Fiennes portrayed Lord Voldemort in the 2005 fantasy film "Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire". He returned to the role for other films of the series: "Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix", "Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince", and both "Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 1" and "Part 2". In an interview with "Empire" magazine, Fiennes said his portrayal of Voldemort was an "instinctive, visceral, physical thing".
In "Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire", Voldemort is initially only heard, possessing the scratchy, weak voice heard in the first film. By the film's climax, however, he appears in his physical form for the first time, played by Ralph Fiennes. As in the book, Voldemort is shown clad in dark black robes, being tall and emaciated, with no hair and yellowish teeth; his wand has a white tone and the handle appears to be made of bone; his finger nails are long and pale blue while his toe nails appear to be infected. Unlike in the book, his pupils are not cat-like and his eyes are blue, because producer David Heyman felt that his evil would not be able to be seen and would not fill the audience with fear (his eyes do briefly take on a snake-like appearance when he opens them after turning human, but quickly turn normal). As in the book, the film version of Voldemort has snake-like slit nostrils with the flesh of his nose significantly pressed back. Ralph Fiennes' nose was not covered in makeup on the set, but was digitally removed in post-production. In this first appearance, Voldemort also has a forked tongue, but this element was removed for the subsequent films.
In "Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone", Voldemort's manifestation is as a face on the back of Quirrell's head, an effect achieved by computer generated imagery. Ian Hart, the actor who played Quirrell in the same film, provided the voice and the facial source for this character. Voldemort also appears in a scene in the Forbidden Forest where he is seen drinking the blood of a unicorn. As Voldemort's face was altered enough by CG work, and Hart's voice was affected enough, there was no confusion by Hart's playing of the two roles. In that film, he was also shown in a flashback sequence when he arrived at the home of James and Lily Potter to kill them. In this scene Voldemort is played by Richard Bremmer, though his face is never seen. His next appearance would be in "Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets" as the 16-year-old Tom Marvolo Riddle (portrayed by Christian Coulson).
Lord Voldemort (, in the films; born Tom Marvolo Riddle) is a fictional character and the main antagonist in J. K. Rowling's series of "Harry Potter" novels. Voldemort first appeared in "Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone", which was released in 1997. Voldemort appears either in person or in flashbacks in each book and its film adaptation in the series, except the third, "Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban", where he is only mentioned.
BULLET::::- 2001 - "Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone" as Swedish voice of Lord Voldemort
BULLET::::- Ralph Fiennes as Lord Voldemort, Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix
Voldemort appears in seven "Harry Potter" films, namely "Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone", "Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets", "Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire", "Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix", "Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince", "Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 1" and "Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 2". Several actors have portrayed him in his varying incarnations and ages.
From 1988-91, Hart studied video production at South Mersey College (now part of Liverpool Community College). He portrayed a POUM militia volunteer in the Spanish Civil War in "Land and Freedom" (1995), an unemployed Liverpool shipyard worker in "Liam" (2000). His best known role, however, is that of Professor Quirrell in "Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone" (2001). He also provided the voice of the CGI-generated face of Lord Voldemort.
He is known for giving his Hindi dubbing voice to Ralph Fiennes's role as Lord Voldemort throughout the last Five Harry Potter films and performed along with his colleagues, Karan Trivedi (later replaced by: Rajesh Kava after the fifth film onwards), Parignya Pandya, Nachiket Dighe, Dilip Sinha and Vikrant Chaturvedi who voices Harry Potter, Hermione Jean Granger, Ronald Bilius Weasley, Rubeus Hagrid and Albus Dumbledore respectively, for the Hindi dubs of the film series.
